Title: How do we show that the function which is its own derivative is exponential?
Content: In my calculus class, to show that $\frac{d}{dx}e^x=e^x$ we did something like this: $$\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{a^{x+h} - a^x}{h} = a^x \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{a^h-1} h,$$ and then we defined $e$ to be the base $a$ that makes the limit $$\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{a^h-1}{h}$$ equal to $1$. Now, my question is this: how can we know beforehand that the function which is its own derivative is an exponential function? In other words, if we have $$ \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h} = f(x),$$ how do we know $f(x)$ is of the form $ka^x$ (ignoring the trivial case $f(x) = 0$)? How can we show that there aren't functions of other forms that give the same result?
